conceptualModel.corePrinciple: The fundamental purpose for which a group exists.

categories.description: Groups formed to achieve a professional or practical objective. They are often hierarchical and their existence is tied to the completion of a specific task or function.
definingCharacteristics: Existence may be temporary, dissolving once the task is complete
examples: employees (Holding, head office, branch Office, company, department)

categories.description: Groups defined by the personal connections and relationships among their members. The primary purpose is social interaction, mutual support, or shared identity.
definingCharacteristics: Based on emotion, shared identity, or personal connection
May have no formal end date

categories.description: Groups vested with the authority to make decisions, create policy, or represent the interests of a larger body. They are fundamental to political, legal, and corporate structures.
definingCharacteristics: Members are usually appointed, elected, or granted power
Roles are defined by rules, laws, or a charter

categories.description: Groups that work collectively toward a shared cause, often to bring about change or protect a common interest.
definingCharacteristics: Members are united by a shared grievance or ideology
Power comes from the collective action of its members

categories.description: Groups formed to create a product, perform a work, or compete in a contest, relying on the collaboration and synergy of their members' skills.
definingCharacteristics: Success is measured by the quality of the output or the outcome of the competition
Roles are specialized to contribute to the final product or goal
